captions.text:
Hey guys, I'm Larry
from ammonyc.com.

And today, we're talking about
the top 10 detailing mistakes
that kill your car.

That's all coming up today on
this episode of Drive Clean.
[THEME MUSIC PLAYING]

Mistake number 10 is
a very common one
and extremely dangerous.

That's using an Armor All type
product on your floor mats.

A lot of times I see guys--
they pour Armor
All just like this.

And they scrub it
into the mat.
Makes it look nice and shiny.

But when you're driving your
car, it gets on the bottom of

your shoes and then on
your brake pedal.

And lots of problems
can happen.

The best way to clean your
rubber floor mats is simply
with soap and water.

Scrub them down, dry them,
and put them back in.

Now, mistake number nine is
using the wrong products on
the interior of your car.

Take, for example,
this carpet.

If I were to use car soap on
it, we'd have suds forever.
And we could never get it out.

That would actually
cause mildew.

What we want to use is a foaming
agent that's actually

designed for carpets, just
like this one here.
So give it a little shake.

Now you see that foam
right there?

I'll take a scrub brush, go
opposite directions, put that
to the side.
Take your clean towel.
Mop it up just like this.
See how I'm twisting?

That's going to pull all the
dirt out of the carpet and
into the microfiber towel.

Now, if I had used the wrong
products like this one right

here, it would've been
foaming for days.

And then you put it
back in the car.
It's going to create mildew.

That's why you use the right
products for the right job.

Mistake number eight is using a
solvent-based tire dressing.

As you can see, it's
a bit liquidy.

But when it comes out,
it's extremely
shiny, just like this.

But what happens is over time
as you're driving, you get a
ton of tire sling.

What I recommend
is a tire gel.

Right here we have a
perfect example.
As it comes out, watch.
Now that's tire gel.

It's very sticky
and very goopy.

And when you put it on, put
it on with an applicator
pad just like this.
Let it sit for a minute.
Tap it off.

And then when you drive,
no tire sling.
So remember that.

The most common mistake I see
is mistake number seven.

And that's washing your
car improperly with
these nasty old rags.

Now, what happens is if you were
to use this on your car,

all the dirt would be trapped
on the outside.

You'd essentially be scratching
the paint.

What I like to use is a
mitt just like this.
It's nice and clean.

And what happens is all the
dirt gets trapped inside.

And then you can wash it off
in your second bucket.

So big thing here is when they
get dirty, throw them away.

Mistake number six is definitely
the most annoying.

And I'm talking about
the glass.

What's going to save you is
using the right towels.

Here I have a microfiber
towel.

And here I have a microfiber
window towel.

As you can see, the pillars or
the plush on this is much
thicker than these over here.

This is what's going
to save you.

The first thing you want to do
is take your window cleaner, a

few squirts on a microfiber
towel just like this.

Go straight lines,
straight lines.

Then I like to go to the top of
the glass, pinch it, pull

it all the way down
just like that.

Now, just before it's done, take
a dry microfiber towel
and just buff off the rest.

And that'll make sure that you
don't have any streaks at all.

Inside the windshield is one of
the most annoying parts of
the car to keep clean.

It's awkward, difficult, and
usually not clean after the
first pass.

The trick is to use your right
hand upside down and lay
across the passenger seat.

Also, try to avoid spraying
window cleaner on the

windshield because the mist or
the drips have a tendency to

leave water marks on
the dashboard.

If you're thinking of quickly
wiping the dash after the

drip, I pretty much guarantee
window streaks after that from

the dirt and the oils picked
up from the surface of the

dashboard and then smeared
again on the window.

Believe me, it's a
losing battle.

Now, one of my favorite mistakes
is wiping your car
without any lubrication.

Now, let me back up
a little bit.

I have a friend of mine that got
a bird poo, unfortunately,
on his beautiful BMW.

And the first thing he thought
of was wiping it with this
nasty thing.

You might as well use a scuff
pad to get all that poo off.

And unfortunately,
he put a bunch of
scratches in his paint.

So next time, I gave
him a good tip.

If there's bird poo, dust, or
anything else on this paint,
use a spray wax.
It acts as a lubricant.

Just hit it a few
times like this.
Then use a microfiber towel--
lightly, one direction.

That picks up any of the
dirt, dust, or poo.

Flip the pad over, and then just
lightly buff it clean.
Look how beautiful that looks.

That's one of the biggest things
I see at car shows is

guys using something that's
improper on their paint.

So do everything you
can to avoid that.

Mistake number four is the one
I get the most emails about.

And that's, of course, about the
different types of soaps.

Each of them has its own
purpose, but not all of them
are best for your car.

So we're going to
start over here.

Anything like hand soap or
dish soap is really great

stuff, but it's not always good
to use it on your car.

Now, occasionally, I do use it
if I'm looking to strip the
entire car of all of its wax.

And then usually I'll compound
or polish or do
whatever the car needs.

Now, for a normal wash, like a
Sunday morning wash, you don't

want to use something
like this.
It's really harsh.

All right, well, the brightly
colored soap here is generally

And you find it on most auto
parts store shelves.

And that is not also the
best stuff you want
to use on your paint.

Now, a lot of times, these can
be just a little bit too

aggressive for what
I'm looking for.

Now, over here, I have very
specific paint soap and very
specific wheel soap.

Now, the paint soap does not
remove any of the existing

layers of protection
on your paint.

Now, if you move over here,
this is a little bit more

aggressive because wheels have
brake dust that's really warm.
It's really hot down there.

And they get embedded
into the metal.

So you need something a little
bit more strong, let's call

it, than something you would
use on your paint.

So this is the gamut of
different soaps you
would want to use.

The hand soap, stick
with the hands.
The car soap--
I don't know.

If it's $4 or $5,
I'd think twice.

Really, you want to focus on
soap that is specifically

designed for paint and soap
that's specifically designed
for your wheels.

Mistake number three is more
annoying than it is harmful.

And that's forgetting to double
check your paint after
you wax your car.

Now, as you can see here, wax
is embedded in all these
little bolts here.

And I missed a little
area right here.

So what you want to do
is take your brush.

Hit it with a little
spray wax.
Rub it off on your leg.

Now get in here and just agitate
all this stuff out.

Now, again, it's not the
end of the world.

But there's nothing worse than
pulling up to a car show and

forgetting a big
stripe of wax.
You'll look like a nut job.

So clean it out just
like this.
There we go.

And this little guy right here,
since it's dried-- see,
it's a little bit dry--
it's hard to get off.

So quick little spritz of
spray wax, one wipe, and
you're good to go.

Mistake number two is using a
product that leaves a greasy

film on the interior
of your car.

We don't like to use that
for two reasons.

One, it actually blinds you as
you're driving, and no one
wants that.

And two, it acts like
a greenhouse effect.

So the light comes in through
your windshield, gets trapped

underneath the greasy part,
heats up the vinyl, leather,

or plastic, whatever it's on,
and actually dries it
out and cracks it.

And no one wants to replace any
of those things because
they're really expensive.

So instead, what I use is
a product like Lexol.

And what you do is you put it on
a microfiber towel, just a
few squirts.

So what this is going
to do is protect and
condition your leather.

But it's not going
to make it shiny.

So you put it on
just like this.
It's going to soak in.
Let it sit for a minute.

Turn your microfiber towel
over, and clean it off.

And you're going to get
a nice matte finish.
None of that shiny stuff.
We don't want that.

Leather conditioner is
a great product.

But what I don't use it on is
the shifter knob and the
steering wheel.

Try to avoid those, because you
don't need any accidents.

All right, the number one
biggest mistake I see is using

the same bucket to wash your
paint that you do your wheels.

Now, the two of these should
be very, very separate.

What I do is use two
individual buckets.

As you can see, one is black
and one is white.

I can never confuse
the two of them.

The black one I like
for the wheels.

The white one I use
for the paint.

Now, the big thing here is you
want to use nice, clean, fresh
mitts to work on the paint.

And you can use some nice,
clean, fresh wash mitts to
work on the wheels.

But the difference
is you never want
to interchange them.

The wheel mitts never hit the
paint and the paint mitts
never hit the wheels.

Separating the two of them will
make your car stay clean

and shiny without
scratching it.
That's the number one thing.

If you take anything away from
this video, you do that.

Your car will look fantastic
for years to come.

Bonus tip number one is always
use a grit guard.

I use it in my wash bucket
and in my wheel bucket.

What happens is all the dirt
comes down and gets trapped
underneath here.

So when you're using your wash
mitt, and you can scrub the

top of it, all the dirt will
fall out and fall into these

little holes and not come back
up into the wash mitt and then

back onto your paint or
back onto your wheels.
This is a great item.
It's about $4 or $5, maybe $6.

And it will save your paint
every single time.

Bonus tip number two
is something I
often see at car shows.
And that's the car duster.

As you can see here, one is
extremely dirty and the other
one is clean.

Now, I don't like to
use these at all.

But if you absolutely must, make
sure you take this piece
off right here.

And you can throw it in
the wash and clean it,
just like I did here.

And if you're going to use it to
clean dust off, the way you

want to use it is to just have
it barely touch the surface of

the paint as opposed
to doing this--

smashing it down and
rubbing it in.
That never works.

So again, if you have a little
piece of dust here and you

want to use this, just barely
touch the surface.

Now, I try to avoid car
dusters altogether.

What I use is a great spray wax
that acts as a lubricant.

Hit it a few times
just like that.
The first swipe cleans it off.

The second swipe is to
buff to a shine.

Now, what I'm using here is a
spray wax that adds another
layer of protection.

So I'm constantly adding
layers after layers.

That's much safer and much
better for your paint than any
car duster will ever be.

All right, guys, that's
my top 10 mistakes.

I'm sure there's a
whole lot more.

And I bet you, you
have a ton more.

If you do, put them on
the comments below.

I'm Larry from Drive Clean, and
you've been watching The
Drive Channel.
[THEME MUSIC PLAYING]

comments.text:
I have to find this garage. I'm about to GTA that place :)


Cool video though﻿
comments.author: gv39109yt

comments.text:
I used a car duster on my Mustang, once.... Then I took the car to the body 
shop to have the scratches buffed out of my paint. That was the only time I 
ever used a car duster.﻿
comments.author: Robert Gantry

comments.text:
My dad saw what appeared to be a "scratch" on my car. So to try and see if 
it would come off or not, he took his bare hand and just rubbed it on my 
paint to see if the scratch would come off or not :( Luckily, my car was 
still relatively clean, and it has Opti Coat on it. He still doesn't get 
how his hand could have scratched my paint.﻿
comments.author: Timothy Er

comments.text:
+beat2deth  my point was the guy was over reacting. a little nudge to see 
if something is loose or stuck on your car isn't going to do anything, and 
certainly isn't going to ruin the paint
comments.author: pooft Lee

comments.text:
+pooft Lee if you rub too hard, you can certainly scratch paint. not deep, 
but enough to be easily noticeable on black paint.
comments.author: beat2deth

comments.text: Great guess, it's actually a black Ferrari LaFerrari! :)
comments.author: Timothy Er

comments.text:
+Timothy Er Is it a black ferrari? I'm not sure why you're so upset. 
Rubbing your thumb on a scuff or odd mark isn't going to do much of 
anything, especially if the car is waxed on a regular basis
comments.author: pooft Lee

comments.text: get rid of all your stuff and buy my products because they're the best.﻿
comments.author: Grant K

comments.text:
Problem with spray wax and microfibre cloth is that the cloth will get 
saturated with dust after one or two wipes, then what are you going to do 
with it? If you keep using the same towel, the spray wax won't be of much 
help and you WILL still scratch your paintwork.﻿
comments.author: Howe Tuck

comments.text: +Howe Tuck That is why you fold the towel then get another one
comments.author: Emmanuel Llanos

ho ho
why u put sticker on simonaz car wash bottle? any layman could have

comments.text: Microfiber mitt or car sponge?? ﻿
comments.author: Jose Eduardo Guzman Crespo

comments.text:
+Jose Eduardo Guzman Crespo Mitt. Definitely mitt. Never use a sponge for 
anything on a car.
comments.author: badnad13

comments.text:
I am a mobile detailer for many years now and I'm doing pretty well and I 
gotta say this guy exaggerates with all the stuff he is doing on the vid 
and for all the newbies watching I'll tell you you don't have to do all 
that stuff with using different buckets and soaps for rims and paint it's 
all bullcrap to make himself seem smart washing a car is just washing a car 
it's simple and doesn't take a thousand different steps to do it like he 
says but detailing on the other hand is tougher and requires training ﻿
comments.author: Jose Sarmiento

comments.text:

from a guy who's been pretty much in your shoes and is offering free advice

Don't be childish. And don't disrespect the people trusting you with their 
cars. I'd give someone a verbal ass kicking if they showed up not giving a 
shit and had me pay them to scratch up the car

comments.text:

comments.author: jeffrey r

comments.text:
yes, quick detailer have silicones and other lubricants. some quick 
detailers are also spray waxes.  I've used Meguiars and I've used AMMO spit 
spray wax.  Both are good.
comments.author: MrSierra5000

comments.text: The stripes are not straight﻿
comments.author: Benjamin Hickson

comments.text:
What about wax and Polish? 
Which one comes first? Do I polish first and then wax or do I polish last? 
Help!﻿
comments.author: Stacy Mitchell

comments.text: the best wax without going too crazy on price , is autoglym high def
comments.author: silverss onyoutube

comments.text:
wash the car off with 2 bucket method and grit guards to protect your car 
from scratches, then dry the car off and take a clay bar to it to get rid 
of any oxidisation embedded in your paintwork, then you polish it, after 
that the wax should always be the final and best part of a detail as it's 
mostly preparation before this stage that gives us the best results
comments.author: paulyyy09

comments.text:
What I do is use a coat of "cleaner wax" first with is like the same as 
polishing then use a carnauba wax to give it the sleek shine
comments.author: hi im paul

comments.text:
If you're talking about getting rid of something like swirl marks by using 
a polish, definitely do that first. If you put a coat of wax on the paint 
and then try to polish it, you'll just strip the wax right off the car.
comments.author: Dallas Freeman

comments.text: This has to be the Sham-Wow's brother.  Great tips nonetheless. ﻿
comments.author: Angelo Beretta

comments.text:
Ummm, i came here lookin for actual professional tips. But this is like 
super basic shit. If you didnt know any of this already, what the hell are 
you even doin washing your car?? Stick to those automated drive through 
things. Or keep scratching the hell out of your car with those brushes at 
the other car washes. ﻿
comments.author: eightymopar

comments.text:
+eightymopar This one is a basic overview. Go to Larry's site Ammo NYC and 
watch his more advanced videos. They're really good. Some people think it's 
going to be all-advertising, but he really doesn't do that. He recommends 
all kinds of tools and types of products to go with his techniques.

comments.text:
BEST stuff for windows is "Driwash-N-Gard". it's american and brilliant on

comments.text: What can i do about dust on my dash and console? any tips﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: JP Dempsey

comments.text:
How do you keep the microfiber fibers from sticking to glass? I always have 
a problem with that when I do glass.﻿
comments.author: carguy53

comments.text:
+carguy53 It sounds like you've washed the microfiber with cotton. This is 
death to microfiber. You have to keep it separated from cotton at all 
times. There should be no fibers coming off of your microfiber otherwise.
comments.author: Tim Angers

comments.text: Vipe your Viper with the viper towel﻿
comments.author: ThreeDriv3rs

comments.text: I didn't know washing your car requires skills.﻿
comments.author: Arya Ahmadi

comments.text:
+Craig Schultz I'm pretty sure anyone can buy your neon for its 500 black 
book value
comments.author: boulderburwell

comments.text:
+Arya Ahmadi This just highlights that fact. You think you doesn't require 
anything, which means you are ignorant of different methods of doing things 
that would be correct or incorrect.

You probably wash your car with a rag and dish soap in the same bucket. You 
strip all of the wax off the car, so it has no protective coating and it 
gets dirtier much faster. You put tons of swirl marks and scratches in it 
when you wash it, and at the end of the day it is less clean than doing it 
the right way. 
This may appear to work on a new car, but look at a car that is 30 years 
old and you will be able to tell how it was cleaned regularly.
comments.author: Ian Mcdowell

comments.text:
Too busy with kiddie fiddling to have time to polish the metal turd on the 
social housing driveway eh mohammed?

comments.text: Funny

comments.author: Ben Ahmedi

comments.text:
+Ben Ahmedi You're the first one I have encountered. 
By the way you look exactly like my cousin; we might be related. In fact, 
in this small world, I wouldn't be surprised if you turned out to be my 
brother bro. So...what I want you to do is, give me you're Social Security 
Number. This way I'd be able to look you up and find out more about our 
relativity (E=MC^2). 
I can also steal money from your bank account if you tell me the number, so 
DON'T.

car is no different.

comments.author: Rc Shott

comments.text:

You know nothing of me. Tell me my yearly income and Balance sheet numbers. 
Even an approximation. Go on. My god your ignorance is spectacular.
comments.author: gus bisbal

comments.text:
+gus bisbal - You would be wrong. I don't own and never have owned garage 
queens.  All the cars I have owned and later sold have been daily drivers 
with 7,000 to 15,000 miles a year added to their odometers.

Beyond that, I doubt you could afford to pay the blue book value of the 
cars I've owned and later sold.
comments.author: Craig Schultz

comments.text:
+Craig Schultz Sir, I would also say that you don't drive your vehicles 
very much. You buy a vehicle that has 20k miles on the clock and you put 
30k miles on it while you own it, I ain't buy that thing for what you 
bought it for.
comments.author: gus bisbal

comments.text:
If that wasn't intended to be sarcastic, washing one's car requiring skills 
depends on how much resale value one hopes to be able to maintain.  I've 
never bought a new car but at the same time, I've never sold a car I've 
owned for less than I paid for it originally because within a few weeks of 
getting a "new" car, the finish is flawless with no scratches, swirl marks, 
spiders' webs or any other surface defects that contribute to a lower value.
comments.author: Craig Schultz

comments.text: That Viper looks EPIC!﻿
comments.author: Arya Ahmadi

comments.text: Can anyone tell me who this guy is?﻿
comments.author: hrthrhs

comments.text:
He's a professional car detailer who has come up with some chemical 
combinations on his own and which he also sells.  I've never seen any 
videos of his that are about general detailing tips, tricks be technique 
where he mentions his own products though.

Personally, I use a couple of his products as well as some from other 
top-end detailing products manufacturer/vendors.
comments.author: Craig Schultz

comments.text:
Armor all on your floor mats are you dumb ass hell. Whoever does that def. 
needs to have their car washed and detailed by someone else with common 
sense﻿
comments.author: Andrew Duggins (Iceman)

comments.text: I've seen and heard of worse.  Tire shine on the treads.  Whoops!
comments.author: Craig Schultz

comments.text:
This guys spot on! Attention to detail , with bird shit, I use a wet tissue 
if its dried on, put the tissue on top let it soak a while then comes off 
with the tissue.﻿
comments.author: theeroom

comments.text:
+ChiefShittingBull On a submarine I served on, the Captain would compete 
with the Radar operator as to who could dunk a bird faster, the Captain on 
the Conning tower with his M-16 or the Radar operator with his Radar 
transmitter.

The Captain usually won but by no means because the Radar operator on duty 
let him. Unofficially, a given Radar set operator's evaluations were 
determined in part by how many competitions he won or, how many birds at 
least had singed feathers, along with a single bullet hole.

Fun facts to forget.  LOL

Yes use Dawn dish detergent when you want to strip the car of wax. There 
are a lot of tricks to the trade like one that has been working well for me 
is using windex to clean all the plastic inside the car. And letting the 
tire shine get on the rim it also makes it shine better. However you have 
to clean it more. I never power buff my cars always hand wax. Don't be 
afraid of trying new products on your car.

comments.author: Tchendje Neves

comments.text:
Excellent advice and tips.  I can't say I'm very mechanically inclined, but 
I do frequently wash, clean and detail my car and take pride in showing it 
off at shows.  Get all the information you can and learn as much as 
possible.  Having to go through the results of poor product, tool or 
technique is never fun.

I'm guilty of the car soap on mats, but removed them and soaked them 
significantly, multiple times while hanging to make sure all the soap was 
gone and hang them to dry in the sun for a while before putting them back 
in the car.  I only did this for the initial interior cleaning after I 
bought the car (Road salt!  Never again!) - I now stick to proper carpet 
cleaner and scrubbing as shown in the video.

My favorite mistake is using harsh cleaners on wheels - I used it on weekly 
washes but, even with prompt rinses, started to wear down the coating.  
I've recently bought new wheels and it's just water, soap and wax for them!﻿
comments.author: Jay Zeus

comments.text: do you wash the washmits after each use, or just thrown them away?  Thanks﻿
comments.author: therazz07

comments.text:
+therazz07 Have you seen those green microfiber mits with the nubs that 
make them look like a Muppet? Those are fantastic on the paint. I wash them 
with the rest of the microfiber each time. Use a wool mit on the wheels. 
Rince it out each time, and throw it away when it gets matted.
comments.author: Tim Angers

comments.text:
You forgot about drying your vehicle. Most people forget this part but it's 
just as important as cleaning your car properly. Use a proper blower that 
is made for cars or, in a pinch, use super soft premium microfiber towels 
but only place delicately on the car and dab. Do not rub! Remember that the 
water you are using has harmful chemicals in it. ﻿

comments.author: hopebear06

comments.text:
If you want to get grime out of PLASTIC/VINYL floor mats, use Lysol Basin 
Tub and Tile Cleaner (the kind that foams via aerosol out of the can). 
 Spray it on, let it work a bit (out of the sun, remind you) and scrub with 
a brush.  Rinse.  Your mats will be clean of dirt.  Be careful though that 
you don't use a cleaner with added bleach.  Applying a top dressing after 
cleaning the mats, like a nice flat ArmorAll will restore a nice color 
depth.  Lysol BT&TC also works well to clean filthy tire rubber.  As always 
watch out for overspray.  ﻿
comments.author: Buzz Cutt

comments.text: How would you clean and polish your exhaust?﻿
comments.author: Greg Murch

comments.text:
Nevr-dull , yes that is the correct spelling. If you have something severe 
on a stainless steel, you can wetsand with very high grit 2-3K, but be 
careful with your sanding pattern. I removed black overspray on a 350z 
NISMO catback that was not covered during a paint job. I have been able to 
maintain the factory stainless tips with multiple passes with Nevr-dull and 
a lot of elbow grease every few months. For chrome tips, use distilled 
water and a good chrome polish.

comments.text: BEST SOAP IS PALOLIVE APPLE LOL﻿
comments.author: James Tatum

comments.text:
I use 2 buckets to clean with instead of a grill in the bottom of the 
bucket - one bucket for rinsing the mitt, the other for the soap - since I 
started to do this instead of using the grill, I've found it gives a 
quicker, better clean - I think because it means there is just more water 
in use.  I don't use a mitt on my wheels, I have a microfiber wheel brush, 
and just give them a squirt with some acid free wheel cleaner and then 
scrub them.  Works well enough for my cars, but then I'm not showing them, 
they are just daily drivers (I'm pretty fussy about them though)

For my carpets I use an upholstery cleaning machine (a hand held version of 
the one you would use on your household carpets) that sprays a suitable mix 
onto the carpet then vacs it back up again into a holding tank - only cost 
a hundred bucks for the machine.  Again, much quicker than using a foam, 
scrub brush and towel, and gives a really deep clean.﻿
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe
